citation.article-title: Novosphingobium taihuense sp. nov., a novel aromatic-compound-degrading bacterium isolated from Taihu Lake, China
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Novosphingobium taihuense sp. nov.
Novosphingobium taihuense (tai.hu.en′se. N.L. neut. adj. taihuense pertaining to Taihu Lake, the source of the sediment from which the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, non-motile rods.
Produces small (about 2 mm), yellow colonies on 10-fold dilution of LB agar, LB agar or R2A agar, after incubation at 30 °C for 3 days.
The colonies are smooth, shiny, flat, non-transparent, elevated and rubbery.
Growth occurs at 10–37 °C, pH 4·5–8·5 and 0–2·0 % NaCl; optimal growth temperature, pH and salinity are 25 °C, pH 6·0 and 0·5 % NaCl.
Positive for catalase activity and nitrate reduction.
Activity of oxidase, urease and arginine dihydrolase, production of indole, growth on citrate, hydrolysis of starch and gelatin and glucose fermentation are all negative.
Other characteristics are listed in Table 1.
The dominant fatty acid is 18 : 1 (36·5 %) and the major hydroxylated fatty acid is 2-OH 14 : 0 (12·8 %).
The predominant isoprenoid quinone is Q-10.

Cells contain phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol, sphingoglycolipid and an unknown polar lipid as major polar lipids; it also contains phosphatidylcholine, unknown phosphoglycolipids and other unknown polar lipids or phospholipids.
The type strain is T3-B9T (=AS 1.3432T=JCM 12465T), isolated from sediment of Taihu Lake, Jiangsu Province, China.
